isis.stitle: SPICER 14 INCH (350 MM) SOLO CLUTCH - OPERATION - OPERATING PRINCIPLES

svcprocinfo.para: The Solo clutch operates under indirect pressure. The pressure springs are isolated from the pressure plate and the spring load is applied through six levers. As the clutch wears, the internal sliding cam adjusting mechanism maintains the pressure plate load and release bearing load in a like-new condition. A tab, visible on the outer surface of the cover assembly, indicates the wear condition of the clutch and ultimately when replacement is required.

svcsubproc.title: Engaged Position
svcsubproc.para: Pressure plate load is the result of axial load of the springs multiplied by the lever ratio. The pressure springs are positioned at an angle to the centerline of the clutch with their ends connected to the adjusting ring and the release sleeve retainer assembly. When the clutch is engaged, the release sleeve retainer moves toward the flywheel and the pressure springs pivot without bending or buckling and apply clamping load to the pressure plate through the levers.

svcsubproc.title: Released Position
svcsubproc.para: When the clutch pedal is depressed to release the clutch, the release bearing assembly and pressure plate move away from the flywheel. Since the clutch clamping load is removed, power from the engine to the transmission is no longer transmitted.

svcsubproc.title: Engaged Position When Wear Occurs

figure.caption: Figure 3. Engaged Position When Wear Occurs

svcsubproc.para: The Solo clutch automatically adjusts to compensate for facing wear. As the pressure plate moves toward the flywheel due to facing wear, the sliding cam adjusting ring rotates and re-establishes the release bearing and internal springs to an as-new position for continued clutch life.
